verses.verse: Job Replies: There Is No Mediator Then Job answered:
(Rom 3.20) “Indeed, I know that this is so, but how can a mortal be just before God?
(Ps 143.2) If one wished to contend with him, one could not answer him once in a thousand.
(2 Chr 13.12; Job 36.5) He is wise in heart and mighty in strength; who has resisted him and succeeded?
He removes mountains, and they do not know it when he overturns them in his anger;
(Job 26.11; Isa 2.19, 21; Hag 2.6; Heb 12.26) he shakes the earth out of its place, and its pillars tremble;
he commands the sun, and it does not rise; he seals up the stars;
(Gen 1.6; Ps 104.2, 3) he alone stretched out the heavens and trampled the waves of the Sea; (Or trampled the back of the sea dragon)
(Gen 1.16; Job 38.31; Am 5.8) he made the Bear and Orion, the Pleiades and the chambers of the south;
(Ps 71.15) he does great things beyond understanding and marvelous things without number.
(Job 23.8, 9; 35.14) Look, he passes by me, and I do not see him; he moves on, but I do not perceive him.
(Job 11.10; Isa 45.9; Rom 9.20) He snatches away; who can stop him? Who will say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
(Job 26.12; Isa 30.7) “God will not turn back his anger; the helpers of Rahab bowed beneath him.
How then can I answer him, choosing my words with him?
(Job 8.5; 10.15) Though I am innocent, I cannot answer him; I must appeal to my accuser for my right.
If I summoned him and he answered me, I do not believe that he would listen to my voice.
(Job 2.3; 16.12, 14) For he crushes me with a tempest and multiplies my wounds without cause;
(Job 27.2) he will not let me get my breath but fills me with bitterness.
If it is a contest of strength, he is the strong one! If it is a matter of justice, who can summon him? (Compare Gk: Heb me)
Though I am innocent, my own mouth would condemn me; though I am blameless, he would prove me perverse.
(Job 1.1; 7.16) I am blameless; I do not know myself; I loathe my life.
(Eccl 9.2, 3; Ezek 21.3) It is all one; therefore I say, ‘He destroys both the blameless and the wicked.’
(Ps 64.4; Heb 11.36; 1 Pet 1.7) When disaster brings sudden death, he mocks at the calamity (Meaning of Heb uncertain) of the innocent.
(Job 10.3; 12.6, 17) The earth is given into the hand of the wicked; he covers the eyes of its judges— if it is not he, who then is it?
“My days are swifter than a runner; they flee away; they see no good.
(Hab 1.8) They go by like skiffs of reed, like an eagle swooping on the prey.
If I say, ‘I will forget my complaint; I will put off my sad countenance and be of good cheer,’
I become afraid of all my suffering, for I know you will not hold me innocent.
(v 20) I shall be condemned; why then do I labor in vain?
(Jer 2.22) If I wash myself with soap and cleanse my hands with lye,
yet you will plunge me into filth, and my own clothes will abhor me.
(v 3|JOB 9:3; Ps 143.2; Eccl 6.10; Rom 9.20) For he is not a mortal, as I am, that I might answer him, that we should come to trial together.
(1 Sam 2.25) There is no mediator (Another reading is Would that there were a mediator) between us, who might lay his hand on us both.
(Job 13.21; Ps 39.10) If he would take his rod away from me and not let dread of him terrify me,
then I would speak without fear of him, for I know I am not what I am thought to be. (Cn: Heb for I am not so in myself)
